titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I. and V:15. Sunday— Catarrh still troublesome— Heard Fowler from Matthew 23.23.—and afternoon at St. John’s Church. 5th. Sunday in Lent heard Mr Hawley from Isaiah 46.12–13. Evening with Mr T. B. Johnson—Isaac M’Kim died.

2. V.45. Monday— Up again in the Night— H.R.U.S.— Pickens. Betts—Palfrey—B. H. Howard announced the death of I. M’Kim. Resolutions— Funeral Arrangements. F. Thomas— Howard’s Eulogy. Comee. of Arrangements Howard—J. Q. A. H. Johnson, Miller Cambreleng, Robertson, Glascock— Arrangements agreed upon in the Clerk’s Office— To meet at Gadsby’s to morrow Morning— Interment at Baltimore— Fisher’s paintings— Dr Thomas— T. B. J. Frye— Handy’s— Mrs Stewart.— I. H. Adams ill—Fire— Mrs Latimer’s Barn

3. IV and V. Tuesday— Fire— Funeral of Isaac M’Kim. Committee of Arrangements— Taliaferro in place of Robertson Pall bearers— From Gadsby’s at 11. to the Capitol— Prayer and Address by Mr Slicer— Walk in Procession to the Cars— Baltimore at 1/2 pass three— Immense crowd of People—procession to the grave—funeral service short by Revd. Mr Wyatt—return to the Cars— Speech by Howard’s brother—my Answer— Most of the Members remained to dine— We dined 9. Miles from Baltimore— Thomas viaduct— Obelisk built by John M’Cartney of Ohio— Pipes of the loco-motive burst— Howard and Thomas return by the Cars coming from Frederick to Baltimore— New loco-motive comes to us from Baltimore— We start at 9. P.M—reach Washington at 1/2 past ten— My Carriage in waiting and brought me home— Cold day—
4. V:30. Wednesday.—

Isaac H. Adams confined to his bed; very ill— My own Catarrh not abating— H.R.U.S— Rules suspended— On and after next Monday the House to meet daily at 11. A.M.— The day consumed in debating Resolutions of the Committee of Accounts, for fixing the appointment, number and compensation of Messengers, and pages or boys, employed for the service of the House and its members— I very unwillingly took part in this debate. W. Cost Johnson, E. Whittlesey, Dixon H. Lewis, Wise, Haynes, Patton, Waddy Thomson, Dawson, Rice Garland, and Thomas also engaged in it— The Postmaster of the House, is merely a sub altern to the door keeper— The Messengers and boys have been hitherto appointed by the door keeper only— One by Statute and two by usage have been appointed by the Clerk— I moved an amendment by which they are henceforth to be appointed, with the approbation of the Speaker— Pedrich and J. Connell here this Evening— Rumour of J. R. Poinsett’s death—

5. V:30. Thursday— M’Caleb— 8th. Article of Florida Treaty. Committee of Manufactures—Adams, Naylor, Slade—Tillinghast, Vail, Webster present— Biddle, Foster and Hunter absent.
To send for Mr Lindsley to meet the Committee next Thursday morning at 10— Spoke to Noland. H.R.U.S. Patton told me he was going— ProfessorJohnson—to ask for the use of the Hall, to deliver a Lecture— M’Kennon moves to choose a door-keeper—debate— House determine to choose now— Joseph Follansbee chosen at the 6th. Ballot— Professor Johnson called this Evening— T. B. J. Frye here— Smithsonian bequest.— Stubborn Catarrh— Miss C. E. Johnston dined here—

Visit to take leave, from the Attorney General. H.R.U.S— Rice Garland’s retrenchment Resn. Motion to suspend the Rules— Yeas and nays 94 to 55. E. Whittlesey’s Bill to constitute a Commission to settle claims agt. U.S— debated— Tenure of Office— Whittlesey—Henry— My objections J. Sergeant, Legare—Underwood— Committee of the whole Corwin in the Chair— No conclusion— The Bill made the order of the day for to-morrow— My wife taken ill— T. B. J. Frye dined with us.

7— V. Saturday— Distressing night and afflicted day— My wife extremely ill— My Catarrh perhaps not worse— Mr Johnson rode with me to the Capitol.— Rice Garland’s motion repeated yeas and nay to suspend the rules 74 to 60— The Commission of claims Bill— Bond— Tillinghast L. Williams Committee rise and report progress—leave to sit again— Order of the day for next Friday. John M. Patton’s Letter of Resignation read— G. Granger—promised to call on me Monday or Tuesday Morning— Mr Johnson dined at Mr Smith’s— Rain—

8. V. Sunday— Rainy day— My Catarrh oppressive— At St. John’s Church.— Mr Hawley— Prayer for Sunday before Easter Stranger preached from Hebrews 13.16. No afternoon service— Evening in forced idleness.

9. V. Monday— Quiet Night— Exceedingly unwell this morning— Mr Frye here The Milldam— Mr Johnson left us, to go and live with Kervand 3 miles out of the City— Mrs Nowlan Mrs Frye dined here. Midshipman John Quincy Adams
came in from Medford— Archibald Campbell andH.R.U.S. met at 11— Hamer asked for the suspension of the rules to take up his resolution they were . . . to 71 not two thirds— Petitions received— I presented.Laid on the table— Mr Bicknell with Letters from L. Humphrey and Minott Thayer— Wrote introduction to Postmaster General Bond’s Speech on Hopkins’s retrenchment Resolutions— Navy Appropriation— Exploring expedition— I spoke to support the Appropriation—a spirited debate then followed—no conclusion My wife extremely ill this Evening— Sent for Dr Huntt double blister. I took to the bed in the upper chamber— J. Q. Adams 2d
Eclipse of the Moon.

10. VI. Tuesday— Visit from F. Granger— Dr Huntt— Bicknell H.R.U.S— Bond’s speech on Hopkins’s retrenchment and reform Resolution—continued— Navy Appropriation Bill— Exploring expedition— Wise, Mallory, Montgomery—Bronson—J. Sergeant— Cushman’s previous question fails— Motion to reduce the appropriations rejected by yeas and nays 91 to 57. John Quincy dined with Captain John Barney— Campbell here this Evening— Unable to read or write— My wife still very ill— Mrs Frye—
Sun rose V:30. S.E. corner ofrow.

11. VI:30. Wednesday— Agent of the Colonization Society for subscription to the Christian Statesman newspaper. H.R.U.S. Report of the Comee on the District of Columbia, asking to be discharged from the further Consideration of Wise’s Resolution to recede the District of Columbia, to the States of Maryland and Virginia.— Bouldin moved to lay the whole on the Table me frustra remonstrante— Afterwards Wise came in and asked a re-consideration, which Harlan moved.moved to lay the motion for reconsideration on the table carried by yeas and nays 82 to 60—against my vote— Bond continued his speech upon Hopkinss retrenchment Resolution— Navy Appropriation Bill— Mallory read a Letter from Captain Thomas ap Catesby Jones— Long debate— Hoffman, Wise, Ingham— Bill passed. Cumberland road Bill— Underwood offers a Resolution to cede
the road to the States, and makes a speech—and calls for the yeas and nays— Campbell of South-Carolina supports the Resolution— Boon of Indiana, opposes, and Pope announces a speech, and moves to adjourn—carried— Walk home— Isaac Hull dines abroad with Campbell— Louisa with Mrs Smith—

12. VI:30 Thursday— Committee of Manufactures at 10— Only Tillinghast and myself there— No business—no Quorum— Reports of Comees absorbed the hour— Naylor asks leave to offer two successive Resolutions; and suspension of the rules—not granted— Cumberland road Bill— Pope, Holsey, Rariden, Mercer and the whole range of the internal improvement controversy— Haynes rose to speak and the House adjourned— Evening visit from Mr Grennell, with Mr M’Kay, agent with the Cherokee Indians— Order from the War Department—Taylor brevetted as Brigadier General—Jesup recalled— Scott ordered to the Cherokee Country— Evening idle.

13. V. Friday. Campbell dined here— Wordena youngfacheux— H.R.U.S. Cambreleng reported a Bill to re-issue the Treasury Notes repaid into the Treasury— At motion of Whittlesey, the claim Commission Bill was postponed till next Friday to take up private Bills not to be debated— Committee of the whole, Atherton in the Chair—every Bill taken up, debated.— No Quorum— Comee. rose and reported the fact— I moved three times a call of the House—refused— Resn. to take up undebatable Bills rescinded— Comee. of the whole— Lyon in the Chair on the debateable Bills— One Bill debated—question to report the Bill— No quorum— Comee. rise and report the fact— Underwood moves a call of the House—160 members answer, and the House adjourns— Evening as idle as the day
14. V.45. Saturday

My two grand daughters finished reading with me the Old Testament— H.R.U.S— Bond, finished his Speech on Hopkins’s Retrenchment Resolution— Comee. of the
Lyon in the Chair—private claims—debate on allowance of interest upon old claims. Heman Allen moves to strike out the enacting clause of sundry Bills— Taliaferro’s counter-argument—claim rejected. 2 or 3 Bills passed— Adjourned before 4.Barziza, brought Letter from H. A. Wise— Gave him a Letter for Govr. Everett. Idle Evening— I. H. and J. Q. Adams dined abroad [symbols]

15. V:15. Sunday— Campbell—and Midshipman Reynolds here— Campbell dined with us.— At the Presbyterian Church, heard a stranger from Hebrews 12.–1. The two children with me They began reading with me the New Testament and Apocrypha— Snow—Sleet—Hail—Rain—peach trees in blossom— Evening Psalms— Analysis of the two Treasury Bills— Return to bed-chamber— No afternoon public worship. Easter day—

16— IV:45. Monday— Visits from Jotham Lincoln and Thomas Whitcomb— Evening call from Mr Frye— Two contracts— HRU.S. Petition day— Hamer backs out— Wise’s Memorial and motion for receding the District of Columbia— Shields’s Resolutions of the Tennessee Legislature—laid on the table— Cushing’s Call on Secy Treasury— Lies over— My call upon P.US—attack of Mexican armed vessel on Steam boat Columbia—adopted— Hopkins re-offered Hamer’s Resolution—lies over. Menefee asked to make a statement— Suspension of rules refused to Menefee, Hopkins, Wise, Shields and Cushing, all by yeas and nays— I presented 5 petitions— J. Sergeant confined to his lodgings— Toland, Goode, Espy, Committee on Meteorology to meet at 10. to-morrow Morning—

17. V. Tuesday— Comee. on Meteorology—Connor, Phelps, Goode, and J. Q. Adams present— Absent Sergeant, Foster and Legaré— Mr Espy conferred with the Comee.— I was instructed to move for the use of the Hall—to-morrow and Thursday Morning from 9 to 11.— I moved accordingly—objection made— Reports of Committees called— When the call from Select Committees came, I moved again for the use
of the Hall for Mr Espy to lecture, and after a dirty struggle to refuse, obtained a majority vote for it— Dr Haynes told me, that for certain reasons he had voted against Mr Buckingham’s having the hall—but that he had voted for Mr Espy’s having it now— Govr. Lincoln moved to suspend the rules to take up the bill for taking down the walls now partly built for a Treasury Department; and using the Stone for a Post-Office building— Carried— Comee. of the whole on the Union. J. Pope in the Chair. Bill debated till 4. O’Clock— Comee. rose and house adjourned. Isaac Hull Adams dined abroad— T. B. J. Frye dined with us.
18: IV:30. Wednesday

At the Capitol at 9. A.M— Heard Mr. Espy’s first Lecture on Meteorology—Rain, Storms, Tornado’s and the dew-point— H.R.U.S.— House refuse to take up the Treasury building Bill—reconsideration of the rejection of Cumberland road Appropriation Bill—carried— M’Kennon moves previous question on the Bill—lost 64 to 68. Underwood moves to recommit the Bill with instructions to report another ceding the road to the States—his Speech— Southgate, Graves— Dromgoole’s amendment to Hopkins’s retrenchment resolution— Adjourned at 4. John Quincy the Midshipman left us for Norfolk to embark in the John Adams. Letter from Amos Kendall, about the Millrace and trees.
19. IV:45. Thursday

Mr Frye was here this morning— I executed the lease of the House and Square 173. to M Erb—and agreed to refer Mr Amos Kendall to Mr Frye, for an answer— He took the Indenture for reconstructing the Mill dam, with Easby, for further preparation— Heard part of Mr Espy’s second meteorological Lecture—belated— Committee of Manufactures— Adams, Naylor, Slade, Tillinghast, Webster—absent Biddle, Foster, Hunter Vail— Senate-Bill 175 for refunding duties on rail-road spikes considered—discussed—adjourned to Monday next 1/2 past 9. H.R.U.S— Dromgoole’s Amendment to Hopkins’s reform
Resolution— Dromgoole’s Speech— Wise’s answer— James Garland takes the floor— Hour expires Sherrod Williams moves suspension of the rules, for an investigating retrenchment Committee 101 to 74 not two thirds. L. Lincoln moves suspension of the rules to take up the Treasury building bill—lost— Cumberland road bill.— Underwood’s amendment— Underwood—Cushing, Rhett, John Calhoon— Underwood again for explanation—snarl. Adjourn— Call at Miss Corcoran’s to see J. Sergeant—too ill to see me— Saw his two daughters— Fremont and Campbell dined here— Catarrhal Evening—

20. V— Friday— Restless and almost sleepless Night. H.R.U.S. James Garland made part of a Speech on Hopkins’s Motion— Rules suspended at Cambreleng’s motion to take up instead of private business the Cumberland road appropriation— Rhett—Pickens, Clowney—all floored by Corwin— Previous Question— Call of the House— Pickens moves to lay the bill on the Table lost Bill passed to a 3d. reading—100 to 95. to-morrow moved. lost Thomas moves 1st. Monday in May—lost question of order made by Bell— Speaker decides against him, afterwards retracts. Previous question— Bill read 3d. time and passed— Adjourned 1/4 before 6.— Campbell and Fremont here this Evening— Legaré declines meeting the Committee on Meteorology— Foster agrees to meet Tuesday Morning at 1/2 past 9— Choaking Catarrh— F. O. J. Smith spoke to me again for Letters— I met this morning the meteorological Committee—Goode, Phelps, and Conner, were there— Sergeant, Legare and Foster absent— I was directed to present the Memorials and move their reference to the Comee. and that with the documents they be printed which I did and the reference and printing were ordered.
21. V. Saturday—

H.R.U.S. late. James Garland occupied the first hour upon Hopkins’s Resolution, with Dromgoole’s Amendment—to which Sherrod Williams moved another amendment his own proposed Resolution and spoke— Cambreleng F Thomas moved to suspend the rules and set aside private business again but failed 87 to 92
Bill for the relief of the heirs of Philip Turner deceased—a question of interest to be allowed on a commutation claim originally rejected, and finally allowed and settled in 1808— Committee of the whole had reported to strike out the enacting clause— Heman Allen of Vermont had alone opposed the Bill in Comee. of the whole, as he now did in the House. It was supported by Craig, Shepperd, Tillinghast, Haley and especially Wise in a long speech— Previous question carried. Bill rejected by yeas and nays 75 to 76. Wise and Mercer voting aye and then having their names erased as interested in the question but not the case— Toucey reports from the dueling Comee. moves printing of the Report and vouchers, and to postpone the subject to next Monday fortnight— Robertson objects to the printing— Grennell presents a minority Report for himself and Rariden—and Elmore a report for himself.— Sharp debate in prospect— Adjourn without taking the question— Campbell dined with us— Mr Frye and Mr Pope here this Evening— Executed the Agreement with Easby—to be kept by Mr Frye—for rebuilding the Mill dam.

22. VII. Sunday— Quite ill in the Night, and this Morning— Called up Mrs Goode— Fever— Oppressed lungs— Heard at Presbyterian Church Mr Gurley from Matthew 11.5. The blind receive their Sight, and the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, and the deaf hear, the dead are raised up, and the poor have the gospel, preached to them— Mr Fowler absent— My wife with Mary, and the children went this afternoon to see Mr Johnson— I attended at St John’s Church— Mr Hawley read the Evening service for 1st. Sunday after Easter, and preached from Revelation 20.11 [“]And I saw a great white throne, and him that sat on it, from whose face, the earth and the heaven fled away; and there was found no place for them. 12. And I saw the dead, small and great, stand before God: and the books were opened: and another book was opened, which is the book of life; and the dead were judged out of those things, which were written in the books, according to their works— 13. And the sea gave up the dead which were in it: and death and hell delivered up the dead which were in them: and they were judged, every man according to their works— 14. And death and hell were cast into the lake of fire This is the second death 15. And whosoever was not
found written in the book of life, was cast into the lake of fire.” An awful text, and a gentle discourse— No singing. [symbols]
23. V. Monday

Mr M’Caleb was here this morning, and I promised to answer his Letter— He is an agent for Land claims in Florida West of the Perdido— H.R.US. Petition day— But the Report of the Committee on the duel, occupied the whole day— Robertson’s motion to commit the Report to a Committee of Privileges, discussed— Toucey, Elmore, Wise, Menefee, Duncan, Glascock, Fillmore, Sibley, Turney, Fairfield, Cushman,—and myself— I opposed the postponement for a fortnight; and said if the postponement should be rejected, I would move to recommit the report, with instructions to strike out the Resolution, and all the argumentative part of the Report, and report the facts— Adjourned at 4— Mrs Randall and Mary took me to the Capitol— I walked home— Mr Campbell was here in the Evening— Also Mr Byron Kilbourne of Milwaukie in the Wisconsin Territory; who brought me a Letter of introduction from his father, James Kilbourne—
24. IV:30. Tuesday.

Attended this morning the Committee on Mineralogy— Present with me only Connor and Foster— Absent Sergeant, Phelps, Legare, and Goode— The Memorials and documents referred to the Committee had not yet come from the Printer— It was agreed to wait for the recovery of the chairman, and a notification from him of the next Meeting— H.R.U.S.— Report of the duel Committee— Slade who had begun yesterday, finished a long speech this morning— Debate continued by Foster, Fletcher of Boston Toucey, Wise, Thomas, Graves, Boon, Grantland, Grennell, Bell, Pennybacker, Sergeant. Howard made an explanation of what he said yesterday concerning the delay of the Committee of Foreign Relations to report on our differences with Mexico— That they were waiting for further communications— The debate on the duel report was continued by Elmore, Robertson, Arphaxed Loomis, Grennell, Tillinghast, Grantland, Toucey, Pope, Parker, Rariden, Taylor,
Legaré, and Atherton, till Calhoon of Kentucky moved an adjournment, which was carried. Campbell was here this Evening— My Catarrh continues, and I. Hull, is yet severely afflicted with his Cough— I am much occupied with Mexico and Texas— Preston Speech in Senate on Texas.
25— V. Wednesday—

My Catarrhal cough promises to pass away. Dr Huntt is very ill— Dr Thomas was here to visit Hull— Connell was here from Philadelphia— Conversation with him concerning Bank U.S. and N. Biddle— He rode with me to the Capitol— H.R.U.S— Slade who had commenced yesterday, concluded a long Speech on the duel report this morning—followed by Toucey—Foster—Fletcher, Wise, Thomas, Graves, Grantland, Grennell, Bell, Pennybacker and Sergeant— Belln Boon at last called for the reading of the Report— The three Reports were read and the House adjourned— Campbell dined with us—
26. V. Thursday

J. P. Kennedy elected yesterday at Baltimore in place of M’Kim— Committee of Manufactures Present Adams, Slade, Foster, Tillinghast, no Quorum— Senate Bills 175 and 176 discussed, and adjourned to meet next Monday at 1/2 past 9. H.R.U.S. Wise called for the reading of the Evidence reported by the duel Committee— The whole day was consumed in reading, and the testimony was not concluded when the House adjourned— A Message was received from P.U.S. while the papers were reading— Sawyer objects to receiving the Message— The Speaker much disconcerted— Intreats Sawyer to withdraw his objection which he does. Message received but not read— Adjourned after 4. Read in the Speaker’s room the Message— Partial answer to Everett’s call for correspondence with Mexico— Negotiations not finally broken off— The Speaker asks my opinion of Sawyer’s objection to receiving the Message— I said I thought he the Speaker was right— That the Message must be received. He said he had consulted J. Sergeant who was of the same opinion. Walk with the Speaker—ride home—dined with Gouverneur Kemble
H. Clay—J. J. Crittenden—H. Legaré—Mr Fox the British Minister—Mr and Mrs Paulding and their Son, 12 years old—and Miss Kemble— Small rooms, and bonne chère— Whist party after dinner— Clay, Crittenden, Fox and Legaré— Home between 10 and 11.
27. V:30. Friday

Mr Everett lent me his manuscript minutes and Letter concerning our affairs with Mexico— I read them this Morning— Very good— Mr Gurley and Mr Smith a Clergyman of Baltimore here this morning— Project for a ministry of Agriculture, or Home Department— Stansbury had put into my hands yesterday, a manuscript of this Mr Smith and a newspaper upon the subject— I think well of the project, and that an Executive Home Department is a desideratum in our political system— But nothing of the kind will at this time receive countenance from Congress— Still I declared my willingness to promote the object to the best of my ability— H.R.U.S. belated by 10 minutes, by Thomas’s nose-bleeding— Poor Snap— Reading of the duel Committee testimony completed— Speech of Toucey—Chairman of the Committee—bitter and plaintive— Severe upon me— Robertson’s reply— Sir Christopher Musgrave— John Hambden— House adjourn without taking any question— Library— Met Robertson—there— Took out the English Translation of Hennepin— Reuel Williams called me out to enquire about a dispatch from Lord Palmerston to Mr Fox of 19. Novr. 1837. published in the London Morning Post—but not communicated to Congress by—P.U.S. though there has been a later Message to the Senate than the last to the House on the North-eastern boundary— He asked me if I knew any thing of such a despatch— I did not— Walk home from the Capitol— Miss Johnston dined with us— Mrs W. S. Smith here before dinner— Campbell here this Evening— Letter from my Son at New-York— His wife and daughter with him— Coming here. Letter from B. Lundy.— Fanny unwell.
28. V. Saturday—

Change of the Season—nearly to Summer-heat.— H.R.U.S— Robertson finishes his Speech— Toucey—Bronson— Stanley, notices Toucey’s attack upon me— Toucey’s reply— Stanley’s rejoinder. Cambreleng announces that the debate must stop or that the public Treasury will be stranded— Menefee’s sharp answer Wise and Graves enquire if Toucey’s report was intended to charge them with a scramble for the advantage of place in the duel— Toucey disdains all intention of charging them with that or any unfairness— Motion to adjourn soon after 3. rejected by yeas and nays 71 to 96. Motion for a Call of the House— Ordered Motion again to adjourn—carried— Walk home— Saw in the House behind the Bar—Pontois—Montmaur, Montholon. Saligny— Dawson introduced to meRobinson of Maine the member elected in the place of Cilley, and who took his seat in the House this Morning— Saw Clement C Dorsey also behind the bar— Evening visit from Mr Davis of New-York— He seems dissatisfied with the resumption of Specie payments by the Banks at New-York—and with the free banking Law enacted by the Legislature of that State— And says that the last Letter of N. Biddle to me will prove ultimately to contain the sound and true doctrines— That the resumption at New-York and Boston is delusive; and that its object was and its effect will be only to enable a few individuals to make their fortunes.— A bill from the Senate to establish a Commission of claims was read twice this morning and referred to the Committee of Claims—
29. V:15. Sunday.

Heard at the Presbyterian Church a Stranger a very young man from Romans 8.1: [“]There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit. 2. For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath made me free from the law of sin death. 3. For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending his own in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh. 4 That the righteousness
of the law might be fulfilled in us who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.” Calvinistic, fresh from the School— After dinner I attended at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read prayers for the second Sunday after Easter and preached from Numbers 6.23. [“]Speak unto Aaron, and unto his sons, saying on this wise, ye shall bless the children of Israel, saying unto them 24. The Lord bless thee, and keep thee. 25. The Lord make his face shine upon thee, and be gracious unto thee; 26. The Lord lift up his countenance upon thee, and give thee peace. 27. And they shall put my name upon the children of Israël, and I will bless them.”—a discourse on the form prescribed by God to the Jewish Priests of pronouncing his blessing upon the People; which he compared with the benediction of the Episcopal Church— “The Peace of God which passeth all understanding, keep your hearts and minds in the knowledge of God, and of his Son Jesus Christ our Lord: And the blessing of God Almighty, the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, be amongst you, and remain with you always— Amen.[”] In the leisure of the day, I answered a Letter from Benjamin Lundy, at Philadelphia—
30. V:30. Monday.

I had again forgotten that a meeting of the Committee of Manufactures was to be held this morning till I entered the door at the Southeastern front of the Capitol, when recollecting it about half an hour before the Meeting of the House I went immediately to the Committee room, and found there Naylor, Tillinghast, Vail and Webster—so that we just constituted a Quorum.— After considerable discussion, we agreed that I should report, Senate Bill 175 without amendment—being a Bill to refund duties upon rail-road spikes by the Georgia Rail-road company— Tillinghast thought there should be refunded only so much of the duties as would
reduce the price paid for the imported article to what it would have cost if the purchase had been made of Spikes manufactured in this Country. He prepared an amendment to that effect but did not press it upon the Committee— H.R.U.S— Resolution and Petition day— But the privileged question of the duel, took its place and consumed the day. John P. Kennedy the new Member from Baltimore in the place of I. M’Kim, took his Seat— Menefee made a powerful Speech of more than an hour, proving that the paper reported by the Chairman of the duel Committee had never been agreed upon in Committee— Pickens followed by a motion to lay the whole subject on the table; in which he persisted against the earnest solicitations of Graves, Wise and Jones—but his motion was rejected by yeas and nays 28 to 167.

1. I. and V:15. Sunday— I was up at one O’Clock this Morning, and again rose for the day at a quarter past 5. racked with the hemorrhoidal Catarrh— At the Presbyterian Church, heard Mr Fowler from Matthew 23.23 [“]Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye pay tithe of mint and anise, and cummin, and have omitted the weightier matters of the law, judgment, mercy, and faith: these ought ye to have done, and not to leave the other undone”—a discourse upon hypocrisy— The distinction is between the performance of positive precepts and the neglect of moral obligations and humanity— Afternoon at St. John’s Church— Mr Hawley read the service for the 5th. Sunday in Lent, and preached from Isaiah 46.12. [“]Hearken unto me, ye stout-hearted that are far from righteousness: 13. I bring near my righteousness: it shall not be far off, and my salvation shall not tarry; and I will place salvation in Zion for Israel my glory.” I spent this Evening in conversation with Mr T. B. Johnson.— Isaac M’Kim, member of the House of Representatives from Baltimore died about 10. O’Clock this morning.

2: V:45. Monday.— Up again in the Night, and much afflicted with my Catarrhal cough— H.R.U.S— Mr Pickens of South-Carolina came to my Seat to make enquiries concerning Madame Brechard’s school, where my two granddaughters went, until they were taken with the meazles— At the House I saw judge Betts of the U.S. District Court—Southern District of New-York, and professor J. G. Palfrey— Mr F. Thomas came to me, and enquired, if I would consent to act as a member of the Committee of Arrangements for the funeral of Mr M’Kim, which he said would be very acceptable to the family and friends. I answered that I would, not with pleasure, but very cheerfully. Mr Howard, immediately after the reading of the Journal announced the decease of his Colleague, Mr M’Kim, with a very touching, and elegant Eulogy upon his character.— The usual Resolutions were adopted, and the House immediately adjourned.
The Committee of Arrangements are, B. F. Howard, J. Q. Adams, Henry Johnson, of Louisiana, John Miller of Missouri, Churchill C. Cambreleng of New-York, John Robertson of Virginia, and Thomas Glascock of Georgia— The arrangements were agreed upon in the Clerk’s Office— To meet at Gadsby’s, where Mr M’Kim lived, at ten to-morrow Morning; and thence proceed with the Coffin to the House of Representatives where the religious ceremonies are to be performed— Thence, in procession to the rail-road Cars, and in them to Baltimore; to be met there by the procession from the City, and go with them to the grave-yard, and bury the corpse—then return to the Cars and back in the Evening to Washington— I went and looked at Fisher’s paintings— Landscapes—dogs and children, in one of the lower Committee rooms.— Home to dine— T. B. J. Frye dined with us— I stop’d at Handy’s hat shop on my way home— Isaac Hull Adams is confined to his bed with a severe lung fever— Attended by Dr Thomas— Mrs Stewart called on me this afternoon, to urge the speediest possible passage of the bill for the relief of the legal representatives of her brother, William Tudor junr— There was a fire this Evening, which proved to be the stable, behind Mrs Latimer’s boarding House—

3. IV and V. Tuesday.— Baltimore and back to Washington. There was another fire, between 3 and 4 O’Clock this Morning, being the Stable behind Keyworth’s house and shop in the Pennsylvania avenue— Funeral of Isaac M’Kim— At ten O’Clock this morning I attended with the other members of the Committee of Arrangements at Gadsby’s Hotel, Mr John Taliaferro being substituted in the place of Mr John Robertson— At 11 we proceeded, with the body on a hearse to the Capitol, where, in the House of Representatives, where part of the Church Service was read, and an address to the auditory was delivered, by Mr Slicer the Chaplain of the Senate—Mr Reese the Chaplain of the House being absent— The President U.S. and several of the heads of Departments were there, with a full attendance.
